reviewText:
Teen sex comedies are a strange beast.  If they are done just for the sake of raunchiness, they can give audiences (particularly the teen audiences) several cheap laughs, but are quickly forgotten.  A lot of films by the Farrelly Brothers, Adam Sandler, and the disasters foisted upon us by Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer ("Date Movie", "Epic Movie" and "Meet the Spartans") fall into that category.

  However, when the films show a greater understanding of their characters and the hormonal confusion of that age, they tend to be more memorable.  The first "American Pie" film fit that bill perfectly.  Now, we have "The To-Do List", which not only understands what it's like to be a teenager with nothing but sex on the mind, it also understands what it was like to live in 1993.

  The plot of "The To-Do List" centers on Brandy Klark (Aubrey Plaza), a very studious, accomplished and stuck-up high school valedictorian who has led a very sheltered life, partially due to her conservative father and partially due to her on choosing.  Following graduation, she works a summer job as a lifeguard at run down pool and finds herself very attracted fellow lifeguard, Rusty, a piece of man-candy with the all the 1993 cliches:  sensitive guitar playing, ripped abs, and long Seattle-style rocker hair.  Brandy realizes that her insulated upbringing has left her with virtually no sexual knowledge.  So, the highly organized Brandy sets out a `to-do list' of sexual activities she wants to engage in as part of her goal of sleeping with Rusty by summer's end.  The curiosity and embarrassment that ensue are experiences all of us remember during our own `coming-of-age'.

  Aubrey Plaza does a wonderful job of portraying the confused, but determined, Brandy as a curious teenager who is committed to learning about physical activities in her own rigid, regimented way.  Her supporting cast includes her best friends Fiona (Alia Shawkat) and Wendy (Sarah Steele), who talk a big game when encouraging Brandy to go for it with her list, but seem to not be as experienced as they make themselves out to be.

  The audience was in stitches throughout the entire movie (myself included).  Any comedy that can get create that kind of experience for its audience is worth seeing.  "The To-Do List" needs to be on your `to-do list'.

It's relatively safe to say the teen comedy is on the verge of death - at least for the moment.  With so many different films attempting to ride the coattails of America Pie, film writers have been dead set outdoing each other in the "outlandish" department with each new film.  While American Pie can be credited with the modern success of the "sex comedy," it was classics like Porky's, Animal House, and Fast Times at Ridgemont High that set the stage for Pie's eventual success.  In the year's following its 1999 release, several similar incarnations of America Pie were released - including Superbad, Van Wilder, and The Girl Next Door.  Each of these films, and countless others like it, followed the exact same premise, making sex the most important aspect of teen adolescence.  However, due to the over abuse of the "teen sex comedy," it has become an utterly predictable genre, currently lacking originality.  Recent films, such as 21 & Over, Project X, and even American Reunion, have all been commercially successful - yet failed to contribute something new or different to the genre.  Adding to the list of unoriginal teen sex comedies is the new film, The To Do List.

Making her feature-length directorial debut, Maggie Carey writes and directs The To Do List, starring Aubrey Plaza as Brandy Klark.  The year is 1993 and Brady is graduating high school at the top of her class, but she has never had a sexual experience in her life.  Deciding she needs to be experienced before entering college, she makes a "to do" check list of sexual maneuvers that will remedy her lack of experience.  She takes a job at the local public swimming pool, which also happens to be where her "crush," Rusty Waters (Scott Porter), is working for the summer.  From beginning to end, it's a summer full of hijinks as Brandy focuses on finishing her checklist while dealing with her straightforward parents, verbally abusive sister, and drunken boss.  Bill Hader, Rachel Bilson, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, Alia Shawkat, Sarah Steel, Johnny Simmons, Connie Britton, and Clark Gregg also star in supporting roles.

Aubrey Plaza does an admirable job of leading the charge in this humorous, raunchy flick.  Her character has a stern sensibility - unwavering and direct.  And while Plaza is a like-able main character, she's not that loveable.  In comparison to other main characters in teen sex comedies, like Jonah Hill or Jason Biggs, there's really no ambition to root for Brandy Klark.  She exudes far too much confidence to create a believable story and frankly, she really doesn't face a conundrum over the course of this film - other than when or if she should attempt to "close the deal" with her male infatuation, Rusty Waters.  Over the course of the film, her character is too promiscuous for her own good, which doesn't exactly paint a pretty picture for the seemingly meaningless acts of her teen angst.

While the Brandy Klark character and her unbelievably direct ambitions are the major hang-up of this film, the rest of the supporting characters make up for it with a great deal of absurd interactions of their own, making for plenty of unrealistic laughs - if you're into sexual humor.  Some of the scenes really press the limit of the R-rating, including a rather memorable movie theater experience, an encounter in the pool's shower room, and a frightfully embarrassing father/daughter moment during the closing minutes of the film.  Speaking of the father, Clark Gregg, whom many will recognize as Agent Coulson from Marvel's The Avengers, plays Brandy's father - a sheltered parent that is easily embarrassed by his wife and daughters.  Friday Night Lights alum Connie Britton plays his wife and Brandy's mother - the brutally honest parent that openly prepares her daughters for sex.  On the plus side, nearly each and every scene involving Clarke and Britton will provide for a substantial amount of laughter.  Rachel Bilson, who plays Brandy's sister in the film, also provides a handful of laughs with her critical, often verbally abusive language towards Brandy.

The To Do List could easily change its name to "Superbad 2" as both Superbad and The To Do List mirror each other in plot direction, only from the opposite side of the gender spectrum.  Both films put sex on a pedestal for curious teens, with Superbad obviously focusing on the high school male perspective, while The To Do List focuses on the female aspect of sexual encounters.  And oddly enough, both films feature Bill Hader and Christopher Mintz-Plasse in supporting roles.  Mintz-Plasse, who struck stardom as the awkward teen, McLovin, is not as prominent in this film as he was in Superbad.  Hader, on the other hand, plays a similar character - which doesn't take life too seriously and often spends his time doing irresponsible things, like drinking all day and well, drinking all night, too.  Still - in the grand scheme of things, these supporting players provide somewhat important roles for both flicks.

The bad news about The To Do List, which heavily outweighs anything good about the film, is the fact that it will simply remind you of countless other teen comedies, like the pre-mentioned comedies, Superbad and American Pie.  Sure, The To Do List is chalk full of embarrassing, childish moments and sex jokes that will make for a few belly laughs - but the film focuses far too much on cheap laughs and not enough on an intelligible plot.  While popular films like American Pie or Superbad set themselves apart from the rest of the films in its genre, The To Do List doesn't DO anything new.  It's simply more of the same raunchy sexual experiences that a writer dreamed up in order to achieve these uninspiring cheap laugh.  The film's plot works fine for what it is, and at certain points, it's even charming.  But, it's simply unoriginal and features a film premise that is severely outdated and over abused.  For those that love this style of humor, sure this film is worth a view - but for everyone else, this film has the power to easily offend and remains too uninteresting for any rational person to find meaning in it.

GRADE: C-
FNDNreview.com

"The To Do List" (2013 release; 104 min.) brings the story of Brandy (played by Audrey Plaza), who has just graduated as the valedictorian of her 1993 high school class. Brandy has been the academic overachiever but is mocked for still being a virgin. Brandy's best friends Fiona and Wnedy convince her that she needs some 'experience' before she heads off to college at Georgetown. Brandy reluctantly agrees and then runs into Rusty at a party. Rusty is the ultimate good-looking all-American hunk and Brandy has the hots for him. Meanwhile Brandy has made a list of sex activities she wants to accomplish, and her lifelong friend Cameron is 'giving her a hand'. To make ends meet, Brandy has taken a summer job as a life guard at the local pool, where Rusty and Cameron also work. To tell you more of the plot would ruin your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first and foremost, this is a racy movie about sex. If that sounds like it will offend you or turn you off, save yourself the trouble (and money), and check out another movie instead. But if the subject tmatter doesn't offend you, be prepared for a funny movie with lots of racy language and situations. I have to say that I found myself chuckling and laughing a lot more than I had expected, and the audience in the theatre was equally eating it up. This is the debut feature of writer-director Maggie Carey, so it's not guys who were dreaming up the script! Aubrey "Parks and Recreation" Plaza shines throughout as Brenda, but kudos as well to several others (and to me preciously unknown), including Alia Shawkat and Sarah Steele as Brenada's best friends, and a special mention for Scott Porter as the good-looking hunk Rusty, giving a tongue-in-cheek performance. Last but certainly not least, the movie features a stellar soundtrack from the early 90s with songs from 2 Live Crew, Naughty By Nature, Gin Blossoms, mazzy Star, the Cranberries, etc. etc. (Brendy's room has posters on the wall of Pearl Jam and also REM Green World Tour 1989, I suppose the producers couldn't get or afford the musical rights to these superstars.)

Bottom line: this is a racy but funny movie that I found even endearing in a very unexpected way, as Aubrey Plaza will charm you from start to finish. "The To Do List" reminds me in spirit quite a bit of "For a Good Time, Call..." from last year: a light-hearted sex comedy from the woman's perspective. There is a fine line between racy/funny and vulgar/off-putting, and this movie stays within that boundary that you'll smile more often than not. The screening I saw this at here in Cincinnati today was quite well attended for a matinee, and laughing out loud at many occasions, so this movie may have some legs on the big screen. Assuming you are not offended by the subject matter, "The To Do List" is worth checking out, be it in the theatre or on DVD/Blu-ray.

This was a really good production about a young women's introduction into her own sexuality in preparation for college.

It had a lot of laughs, lots of sight gags and the surprising inclusion of Connie Britton and Clark Gregg.

Gregg in particular is given some great lines as he tries to control his daughter's sexuality while simultaneously trying to avoid dealing with it personally.  Britton is the level-headed mother who wants to ease her girl's introduction into adult behavior.  Both of these parts are not so subtle subplots that just make the whole story come together.

Well worth the time to watch.
This is a fun movie to watch. It's funny and I really enjoyed it.

One of my favorite comedies of the last few years. It's everything you want in a raunchy teen sex comedy while also showcasing strong female characters. It falls into some of the usual tropes, and turns other ones on their head, but what do you expect from a movie starring Aubrey Plaza?

There was no way that I was going to give this any less than 5 stars. First of all, NOT for kids. Very funny and raunchy humor. We start with the girl net door who has such plans for her future studying and more studying. She makes a TO Do list of things she needs before beginning college. Her girlfriends seem to think she needs to have other priorities for the summer so anew list is made. Very interesting things on the new list. The cast is marvelous and that is all of them. The jokes are funny and that is all of them and I just had such a great time from beginning to end.

Ordered this as a 'Treat Yo Self' gift and couldn't be more pleased. It arrived very quickly (at least two or three days after ordering!) and was in perfect condition. It's a good gift for any fans of Aubrey Plaza since this is one of her best roles or if you're looking for a good laugh.

This is one of those high-school graduation, coming-of-age films thats supposed to be funny.  The main character is Brandy Klark (played by Aubrey Plaza) a girl who takes everything seriously.  All through high school that meant studying hard to get into college while her girlfriends were more interested in dating and learning to handle social life.  Brandys parents are also so straight that one would guess perhaps they are Mormon, or from some equally conservative background (though the mother turns out to have been somewhat more adventurous in her youth than dad realized).

Anyhow suddenly Brandy becomes convinced she has to learn all about sex because after all, college is really where boys and girls start seriously dating, and shed better know what shes doing in advance.  So in her methodical way she compiles a list and starts trying to check the items off, over the course of the summer after graduation.  Half the items on the list, she doesnt even know the meaning of, and she has to look them up or have them explained to her.

Now I admitI didn't know the meaning of a few of the items eitherthough this still does not compare to the astonishing outburst of phraseology from the Indian salesman in 40 Year Old Virgina list that Ive vowed to go back to someday, watch the subtitles, write it down, and figure it all out, but I still haven't done so.  Nor is the movie in general either as funny or as interesting as that predecessor.  I would describe it as mildly amusing, and fairly harmless
Don't expect much and you'll love it.
Raunchy and hilarious

The To Do List is the type of comedy you should NOT watch with your parents!  Wow would that ever be a mistake of gigantic unforgivable proportions, haha!  It's about Aubrey Plaza's character who's about to enter college and finds it extremely important, according to her friends approaching womanhood, to lose her virginity.  Basically Aubrey attempts to lose it but winds up in situations where she either embarrasses herself due to inexperience or does it wrong which is where the humor comes in.  She learns gradually until it's no longer the main aspect of the story and honestly I don't even know if teenagers act and talk this way.

When I was 18 yeah, of course I'd have conversations about sex with my friends and classmates, but it was always in a joking way.  Aubrey and her friends often have serious conversations which would be a little awkward if this were reality, but I suppose the awkwardness *is* what makes up most of the comedy in the To Do List  I'd like to give some examples but amazon would probably deem them inappropriate... alright one example is how Aubrey, her sister (Rachel Bilson's character- wow haven't seen her since the OC days and she hasn't changed or aged a bit) and the mother are all sitting around the kitchen table talking about the differences in pleasing circumcised or not circumcised men.  Just imagining two sisters discussing such a thing with their mother is hilarious enough, but discussing it while the father who's sitting nearby?  Now that's awesome!  These are the funniest moments for me, other than Rachel and Aubrey criticizing each other (that's what sisters do!) which happens frequently and resorts to funny name calling.

There's a ton of content that's really extreme to the point I can't share (gotta follow amazon's guidelines here!)  Basically the movie's interesting in how it jumps from tame and light-hearted one moment, to downright dirty and offensive the next without much in the way of a warning.  Aubrey's a beautiful woman and actually she's much older than the young girl she portrays in the film interestingly enough which goes to show how young she looks.  Other memorable segments include such the parents walking in on Rachel Bilson doing a man in her bedroom while the guy she's doing it with wants to shake the father's hand.  Now that's hilarious!  Aubrey getting caught doing a man in a van by her father is another classic scene.

The story is entirely focused around sexual talk, but there's no nudity to speak of.  Just really graphic language.  I never quite understood the reason why the story takes us back to 1993.  I mean it could've easily focused on the year it was released (a couple years ago) but I probably missed a crucial plot point that explained it somewhere along the line.  I mean other than Aubrey's obsession with Hillary Clinton, the year really didn't seem to matter at all.  At least a few references brought back memories for yours truly.  Anyway in addition to Aubrey experimenting her sexual appetite on different men and learning what pleases and what doesn't please them sexually, she does this without any emotion or attachment to any of them not because she's sleazy, but because she comes off so clueless all the time.  A guy has a crush on her (Johnny Simmons) even though she doesn't realize how much he actually likes her because she's busy with some other dude (make that a couple other dudes, haha).  This leads to some funny and even sincere moments (possibly the ONLY moments of sincerity).

Aubrey's acting is questionable sometimes.  I've seen her in other films that I can't remember the name of off the top of my head and she was good in those, but here she tends to act nonchalant but I wonder if it's unintentional or not.  Perhaps Rachel Bilson should have played her role instead.  Honestly Rachel looks more innocent in the eyes and personality than Aubrey does and would have been better for the virgin part.  They should've switched the two.  Otherwise, yeah, the To Do List is all about young adults doing each other, lol.  Again, Aubrey goes around not having any personal attachment to anybody quite is odd, and it's all about sexuality exploration.  I find it unusual that Rachel's character is that she's preparing for marriage and yet we never see the husband, and that she herself, despite being the older sister, often acts just as immature as Aubrey.

A movie you're probably better off watching alone or with a group of friends you feel comfortable with who can relate and not be offended by constant sexual situations and language, and certainly nobody under the age of 20 should see this.

This movie should have been about a teenage boy who wants to lose his virginity (and also try a lot of sexual things) before going to college. Instead, it was about a girl. Yes, the boy losing his virginity story has been done a million times. But, with a girl, the slut issue ruins it.

It was very funny, I laughed all the way through, but I also was very grossed out and shocked all the way through.
It held my attention and I couldn't wait to see how it would end.

There should have been a message, such as : "Be careful about sleeping around because it can change your life or even ruin your life,"
such as :
(1) you can destroy your reputation,
(2) you could get an STD, worst of all, HIV,
(3) you could get pregnant, and you may not even know who the father is,
(4) you could play around and end up falling in love and getting a broken heart,
(5) you could break someone else's heart,
(6) you could hurt your friends or lose your friends' respect or lose your friends completely,
(7) you could lose your parents' respect, and
(8) you could live with regret later on, because you lose your virginity only once, and it should be special and memorable.

The movie did hint at these things, but it did not give the message.

It was a comedy, and if the only goal was to be funny, then it definitely was.

It definitely falls under the "raunchy comedy"  category, so keep that in mind....But in spite of that, surprisingly good!

Overall, funny but nothing I would watch over and over again.

This film is like those T and A films of the 80's ( Last American Virgin or Fast Times). Entertaining but embarrassing. Dont ask for much here and you will enjoy a fun little film. As teen sex comedies go this one is pretty light and you can see how it is going to end up in the first ten minutes or so. But if you are a child of the nineties and missed those classics of the 80s then this film is probably for you. I was disappointed the soundtrack was not better. There is some great 90's hits that would of fit the film nicely.

but not in this movie. This is like 'American Pie's' retarded, inbred little sister. She eats poop. Seriously, in the movie her character who is supposedly really smart, "accidentally" picks up in her bare hand, a log of floating poop, and takes a gigantic bite of it. Enough said.
Pretty entertaining. I enjoy Aubrey Plaza but she is not for everyone. Deadpan comedy is an aquired taste but it works into her character in this movie perfectly.
I Absolutely Love this Movie! Rented it on red box and loved it! Walmart,  Target and Best Buy were only selling it online for over $30 -_- I found on here and bought it instantly!
This movie was not funny. I laughed at maybe two things. And I grew up in the 90's too! was not worth the five bucks it cost to rent that's for sure.
There are good people in this move, but it was just gross.  I some point I thought it would get better and hoped for a turn around but instead it just got worse.  We turned it off.
Interesting premise and certainly issues we can all relate to male or female. There were some genuinely funny segments, but it just didn't seem all that well  written overall.
Very funny nostalgic sex comedy from the girl's point of view.  Aubrey Plaza, Rachel Bilson, and Bill Hader in particular are hilarious and human.

If you 're looking for a movie that's funny and will always keep you laughing this is the movie for you. It's one of my favorite movies to this day I can't get enough of this movie, great actors , great plot, just a great movie overall.
Horrible. Bad production and actors. Complete waste of time and money. We wanted an easy movie to watch but this is an insult to ones taste.
It was a funny ,somewhat raunchy comedy. I enjoyed their take on the early '90s and mocking the fashion. I wouldn't recommend this for young teens, it's completely about sex.

Aubrey Plaza has definitely picked up a ton of good habits from her (I assume) comedic mentor Amy Poehler; Poehler's influence might even be behind some early stumping for HRC and subtle ribbing of a certain Utah religion.  There are some decent moments in this film - but like the protagonist they're still awkward and clumsy in the delivery.  Bill Hader and the gent from the Avengers ensure I don't regret spending a couple bucks, but to friends and family I'd recommend waiting until it hits netflix or the dollar bin at Shop-rite.

Eager to see how Plaza develops in future projects - I generally find that she's easy to watch and effortlessly amusing.
This movie was just okay. There are several scenes that are pretty funny, but I don't feel like I would ever watch this movie again.
This movie was hilarious! It was not what I expected. It was very funny and had its relatable moments. It was a raunchy type of film, but it is a MUST SEE.

FUNNY, FUNNY, FUNNY, FUNNY, FUNNY !!!
Great cast and orginal story. A female losing her virginity( not male teens as hollywood norm).
If you are "uptight", don't watch it !!! It is going to bother you !
If you are into American pie, roadtrip, etc. You will love it.
Super funny movies, especially for us women who grew up in the 90's.  Raunchy at times, but nothing over the top, really liked it.
I thought this movie may be dumb, but it wasn't! Great cast and great script! A must see if you love SNL.
This movie is hilarious and raunchy. It's a total must see!  I Don't know why it got bad reviews. It reminded me of the raunchy comedies that came out in the 80's.
Movie night with My fiance looked for something funny this movie definitely left us laughing. Would I recommend this Yes!

I thought that this movie was ok. it had it's funny parts but come on guys lets get a little creative and original there are so many of these high school-collage lets get laid movies that it's overdone. at least in this one its a girl trying to get laid and not a guy. and I kind of think it sends a bad message to teenage girls. it is better to wait and then to rush stuff at least the main character realizes that at then end. it was funny to a point but I would not buy it. and on the cover of the case it says that its funnier than American pie. that is bs right there. well anyways it was ok and some what funny. if you have not seen this movie then I recommend you don't

Funny, ridiculously awkward teen comedy. Will definitely watch again and def worth the rental price. Audrey Plaza is so good. If u have seen her on Parks and Rec u know what im talking ab. She's so good at bitchy and awkward. Plus it's set in what appears to be the 80s but they use words I don't know where even invented yet like "the shocker" haha but it works and it's funny. Not a fun family movie or anything u would watch with ur parents as there's lots of inappropriate humor.
I love this movie based in the 90's It had some great fashion flashbacks. Aubrey Plaza does a great job of portraying a clueless prude who realizes sex doesn't have to be so serious.

This movie was entertaining from beginning to end! I would not watch it with my mom, but next time I watch it, it will be with a bunch of girls and some cocktails. It is totally relate-able and super funny! I will be watching again!!
Most of the times movies sort of lull in the middle of beginning but this one was hilarious all the way through!
Best comedy I have seen in a while.  Great for a girl's night movie or just for some good laughs.  :)
Wasn't a great movie by any means but it was very entertaining. A lot of the same cast from Superbad so expect that kind of movie.
A bit silly, but perfect for a funny, chick flick fix. I really did feel like I was in the early 90s again.
This was a funny movie.  It was worthwhile.  The Parks & Rec chick is a riot and very funny.  Worth it.

Great cast, little laughs. It's actually pretty gross. And I liked "Porky's," if that says anything. Aubrey Plaza deserves better, as does Bill Hader and the rest of the cast. The poop eating scene - really? We needed to see that?

For decades, movies have treated the teenage sex comedy as an exclusively boys-only subject. So it is quite refreshing to have seen this gem: a raunchy, perverted, debauched and completely hysterical sex comedy but with a girl as the lead.

So if you can't stomach the gross-out jokes, foul language and potty humor of an "American Pie" or "Superbad," then stay far away from this one. Otherwise, I think many would find this movie even better than those two.

Besides a rollicking series of great jokes from a fantastic ensemble of quirky characters, this movie is even more intelligent and superior than expected because it wisely disobeys the traditional plot conventions of the genre. Instead of basing the heroine's emotional growth on her falling in love with a boy - a cowardly cliche that is so contrived and dishonest to sell-out the perverted lust of the hero with some corny, redemptive romance - the heart of "The To Do List" is rooted in the lead's relationships with friends and family. The princess who doesn't need to marry a prince, one who can be as debased as any boy... this film is indeed a bold step forward for gender equality, and people learning about pearl necklaces.

Also, Amazon says Andy Samberg is a co-star, but he is only a cameo. Bill Hader gets maybe the most screentime otherwise and is great.

Finally: bonus points if you're a child of the '90s. You will definitely enjoy the plethora of nostalgic jokes about silly throwbacks like Trapper Keepers, Hypercolors and Eddie Vedder posters.
I am pretty tough when it comes to movie reviews, so 2/5. Movie was good enough I guess, but not one I will want to watch again or recommend.
What guy doesn't like a cute chick who is sexually curious?! Haha!! It's a very good comedy movie to see!
Not your typical coming of age story. Had me laughing all the way through. Bill Harder and Clark Gregg give great performances.

Nothing too deep, and overtly sexual, but generally hilarious.  Really enjoyed it as a good mindless escape movie on a lazy Friday night.  A few embarrassingly painful spots, but the laughs stayed constant.

Aubrey is an acquired taste when it comes to her as a person. She is, undeniably deadpan, and it shows in practically all of her works, regardless of character. However, if you can get past the exterior, you can tell she has a heart. The movie is undeniably for those who aren't squeamish about sex, and has male characters who are actually good people, which was not what I expected at all. It's all about owning your sexuality and who you are, and is a great little coming of age flick with a pretty good message. (I don't recommend showing it to your kids, though). I laughed at the navet of 90s high school students--I was born in the late eighties and I can still remember what it was like before Wikipedia, so it's a great nostalgia blast, especially during the beginning credits. Anyway, I loved this little film. I could see myself in the main character. Give the film a chance. You might be surprised.
so funny!  would watch this again because it is so ridiculous. def. weird taboo moments here and there but i could see this happening to a teenager.
Was kind of stupid. But I should have known thanks to the preview. Funny is some parts. Exaggerated in others. Should have waited for Redbox. Not happy I spent $5 for a rental.
I fell asleep during this movie. That pretty much sums up what I think about it. Unmemorable. Do not buy, rent it if you want to see it.
I thought that this movie was ok. It was pretty funny and all but it isn't a must see. I did enjoy it though. Its a great rental movie.
Not funny, empty attempts at super adult humor (vulgar language definitely can serve it's purpose if used properly but here it just falls flat). Disappointing since Plaza is usually pretty great

not something I'd watch more than once, but I do enjoy a little bit of fun nostalgia every once and a while....not much other than that is left in the way of redeeming qualities on this one - which is unfortunate, since I had high hopes!

Aubrey Plaza kills it in this movie. I went in with an open mind and was not disappointed in the least. Many who are saying the main character is disgusting and just uses people obviously didn't sit through the whole movie to the ending, when many revelations about herself, her independence & the "To Do List" are realized. Having a raunchy sex comedy with a female lead is refreshing and shows the other side of the card when all we are usually shown in the male perspective in most movies depicting the rite of passage of losing one's virginity. I really enjoy watching this movie and laugh all the way through. The 90's theme is also a nice nostalgia kick for me. So far everyone I have recommended this movie to has loved it as well.

It's about time someone made a film about a girl going through crazy lengths to get laid!  This movie is hilarious and fits at home with the other common coming of age stories of what young men will do to get sex.  The show is finally on the other foot and it's hilarious.
Laugh out loud from start to finish. The 90's details were dead on and in every detail. Hilarious movie and clever plot.
It was a laugh out loud bring you straight back to "80" comedy. Must see don't judge this book by its cover
list is funny and very well put together with a great cast. this movie caught me by surprise and I had a lot of laughs

This is a funny movie for young people.
It's has its ups and downs with friendship ,for first year college life.
I like just about everyone in the cast so I was looking forward to this movie.  There wasn't anything I really liked about it.

I have heard some people saying that this movie is a "Feminist\Female Empowerment" comedy. First off, it's not a comedy. It would have to be funny to qualify. Secondly, "Female Empowerment"? The main protagonist is a narcissistic sociopath who views other human beings the way everyone else views toilet paper, as usable and disposable. If a man did exactly the same things, said exactly the same things, and had the exact same motivations and emotional detachment concerning what he had done, every woman on earth would say he was a disgusting pig. Making the lead character female doesn't make her actions any less revolting. This movie is a series of awful people using one another and never once treating one another like human beings. If you want funny, go elsewhere, this is just tasteless.
The cast looked like a funny crew and the storyline sounded good. Very good and funny movie overall, 5 stars for sure.
My hubby and I rented this for a date night in and it was great! I would definitely not watch this with anyone younger, including high school age kids. Great for adults who need a pick me up!

This is a corny movie that will make you groan with its predictable plot, hijinks, character development, and teen hijinks.

But it's a great example of how to portray characters who enjoy sex and sexual experimentation without all the purity hang-ups and slut-shaming mind-games that usually accompany movies of this type.  Bravo.

Also, it amuses me greatly to just assume that Agent Colson is operating undercover, and that this is his actual family life when he's not off saving the world with S.H.I.E.L.D.  (Apologies to Clark Gregg for typecasting him)

My girlfriend and I loved this movie. The actors are all fantastic and if you are not the type of person to be squeamish about the subject matter the movie tackles (sex, and lots of it) then you should REALLY try it.

This movie felt like I was watching someone else's nostalgia trip, real and surreal all at once.  The characters make typical teenage decisions, the kind that seem well-thought out and grown-up when you're going through the process, but embarrass you twenty years later.  The ending, I could not have seen coming, as it breaks the mold of other teenage sex comedy.
I liked this one pretty well. The cast is great and there's plenty of funny moments. And Agent Colson is one of the best awkward dads in a long time.
It took me back to when I was growing up and how much I 'thought' I knew.  Had some funny moments.
The trailer is funnier than the movie.  Don't waste your time paying to see this one; it's definitely not worth it.
There were a few laughs, and I appreciated that it was a girl in the raunchy role, but it didn't have the heart I expected. There was no balance.

Disclaimer: I couldn't even finish the movie I found it so raunchy and unengaging with extremely stereotyped characters. So perhaps it could have slightly redeemed itself if I had forced myself to finish. But, since I view comedies to be just that - to be funny and entertaining, I refused to treat it as a root canal and as something I should "push through" just because I paid for it.

The lead character is painfully and offensively stereotyped as intelligent and overachieving and, therefore, correspondingly unattractive and socially inept. Further still, the attempts at humor were cheap, uncreative, and are already extremely overdone in Hollywood. I was not expecting a raunchy, have-as-much-sex-as-you-can-to-be-cool unilateral approach nor is that amusing to me. So, this is the perspective I am coming from. I was anticipating a cute, clever comedic approach exhibiting Aubrey Plaza's unique deadpan humor. I was severely disappointed and disgusted. It was a waste of time and money.

I'm a fan of most of the actors in this film, but I had low expectations of this movie and expected it to just not be funny at all. Fortunately, to my pleasant surprise, this was a hilarious movie that had me laughing at something every couple of minutes. If you like the works of Plaza, Hader, or Samberg, you're going to like this movie.

I'm a huge fan of Aubrey Plaza, but she was not believable as a sexually naive virgin.  She's too hard edged, even when she's trying to act like she's not.  I wish I would have rented this instead of buying it.
Really wanted to like this but overall, was kinda not much there to engage with. OK for Aubrey Plaza fans.
Pretty funny movie, and not as raunchy as it could have been. Bill Hader plays his character really well and the other no-name actors are pretty solid.

I was hoping for so much more from this.  I enjoyed American Pie, 21 Jump Street, etc.  But this movie doesn't even come close to providing raunchy humor, it just falls flat.  I cracked a smile a few times but there was no real comedy here.  It was just an awkward attempt at dirty-sex humor.

Really wished I could say something better, we did finish it to the end, but I kept checking to see how much time was left because it was just getting painful.  Save your money for a better rental.

I will admit that I am a sucker for a good teenage coming of age story.  The thing I liked about this movie was that it was not your average typical coming of age story.  Sadly, it's still rare for a female protagonist to be so open about sexual experiences, or in this case lack thereof.  This story wasn't really about a girl trying to find love, which I found refreshing!  It was funny, though some the humor might not be for everyone.  Some of it might be considered inappropriate or "gross" humor, so this movie might not be for the more conservative types.
It was pretty funny... but you got to keep in mind this movie is not Oscar material or anything but I recommend it if you have nothing else to watch
this may not be for guys. all girls should watch it. the cast is great and it really was well made.

I saw the all-star cast and thought it would merely be an irreverent look at the "straight A" high school kid gone wild. I was wrong. It's way more sexual in content than I had expected (although mostly references) with fewer laughs than I expected as well. There seems to be a great cast, and I usually love Aubrey Plaza's work, but this was a little one dimensional. Overall I'd say it had potential, but it missed its mark.
The movie was pretty entertaining. This movie game me some good laughs. I would recommend this movie if you are not afraid of revealing comedy.

Wow, I don't know why I didn't believe the other bad reviews. My mistake - so so bad. Set in 1993 for some reason? No idea why, had no relevance to the story. Maybe so they didn't spend all there time on the internet? Who knows but it was just so bad.

I thought this was a funny yet slightly raunchy "girl" movie. My husband did not enjoy it. He didn't get the references to the dance moves like the roger rabbit and why the movie beaches is so important. Watch it with your lady friends and I'm sure you'll laugh harder.
Hilarious. Aubrey Plaza is genius in this movie! It can be uncomfortably funny at points, which was expected. If you're a fan of Aubrey Plaza/April Ludgate, you'll like this movie.
The To do List is great becuse of the collection of hilarious characters. The movie is explicit, but its what horny teens think about already. Don't watch if your easily offended.

I thought the movie had a great cast. Considering the movie's content, I was sure it was going to be full of horrible acting and lame jokes. However, I felt like it was cleverly funny and took a new spin on the classic virgin dilemma.

It's nice to finally have a sexual view point from a teenage girl, we have been bombarded by these kinds of movies about guys. Its funny, witty, and times a little over the top but overall good stuff.

Brutal. Simply brutal. First of all, I do like these high school coming-of-age movies even if they all are pretty cliched. The problem with this one is there are virtually no laughs in it at all. Despite a decent cast ("SNL" vets Bill Hader and Andy Samberg, McLovin from Superbad and Tami Taylor [Connie Britton] and Jason Street from "Friday Night Lights," Rachel Bilson of "The OC" fame, Troy from "Community" and Agent Coulsen from "Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D."), it just tries too hard for the gross-out humor and lacks anything clever.

Basically, Easy A beat them to the punch with a better cast and script.

Throw in the odd choice to place the movie in the '90s yet a lot of it looked more like the '70s was bizarre. Seriously, most high school movies are in the now as it's teenagers who watch this fare by and large. Unless I'm missing some untapped group of people in their late 30s who want to relive the '90s?

Extras are plenty but nothing jumps out at you. Honestly, this whole DVD package was really worth what I paid for it--zero. Got it free with another DVD purchase.
Surprisingly good movie.  Very funny!  I did not expect this movie to be as funny ad it was.  It was worth the buy.
Just not funny. However, it is an interesting inversion of gender roles in teenage high school comedies. The nineties references are forceful and as an Xer I did not feel they related to me.
Has moments. If you want to laugh and not looking for an award winning movie then this is worth a shot.
This movie felt like like watching a Micheal Cera or Jessie Eisenberg movie but instead with a female lead as opposed to those guys. . . watch it, reverse the genders, and you'll see what I mean.

I love Aubrey Plaza, so even though the newspaper reviews were ehhh, I decided to take a chance.  It was very funny with some (uncomfortably) true parts.  All those reviewers must have been old men :)
It was fine, but too much for me with the sex going on as if it was the only thing in the world.

A new comedienne Star is born.  Aubrey Plaza is her name and is not afraid to take the comedy to the Carole Burnett nth degree.  Hysterically funny lady in a hysterically funny movie.  Don't expect this to be a typical teen comedy, because it isn't.
Kind of a dumb premise. Not terribly funny- I chuckled a few times throughout the movie, but it wouldn't be something I recommend.
This was a terrible movie.  no wonder it was not in the theater very long.  I'm not sure what to say other than I could not get past the first 25 minutes of this move.

Brandy (Aubrey Plaza) is a 1993 grossly stereotyped virgin and valedictorian. She is convinced she must lose her virginity and become sexually knowledgeable before college. She creates a comical "to do" list, most of which we never see happen. The list, and Brandy's not understanding the terms I found to be the funny part of the film. Once she starts to check things off the list, the film becomes neither funny or erotic. It attempts to be crude with stale humor.

I found Aubrey unable to pull off the role as Emma Stone did in "An Easy A." The "humor" was juvenile with adult themes and fails even as a teen sex comedy.

Might work as a low brow rental.

Parental Guide for R rated version: F-bomb, sex. No nudity. Sex talk.
Raunchy, exciting, blunt, and hilarious this movie does a great job in satirizing the stranger times in our youth.  I would highly recommend it to anyone out of their high school years.
Never heard a thing about this movie before renting it but was glad I did. Was in the mood for some comedy and definitely found it. The cast was awesome and had me laughing out loud.

I'm a fan of many of the cast members, especially Aubrey Plaza. She has a similar delivery to other roles I've seen her in, but it works, so I have no issue with it. I think Alia Shawkat is also amazing. Yes, it's a similar plot we've seen told from the male perspective many times, but it was refreshing to watch it from the female perspective. I loved that it went there with a pretty solid sex-positive message. I was a teenager in the time this film takes place in and the little choices in set design, fashion, and the music were spot-on. I thought it was good fun and did the whole "nostalgic teenage coming-of-age" drama well.

These two sisters are new comedy archetypes that I don't recall ever seeing in a film before.  One knows practically everything about sex and the other less than nothing.  Every scene they had together of crass banter and debate left me in stitches.  Teenagers of today may not believe how naive some of their mothers were but this isn't that far off.  It admits that hooking up just for first time experiences or only because someone is good looking are bound to bring disappointments.  This one succeeds in every way that "American Pie" failed.
It was a bit predictable but overall it was funny. I'm not sure if I would recommend it over some other coming of age films.
Hilarious! Ranked up there with Superbad and Wedding Crashers. Love Aubrey Plaza, Bill Hader, Scott Porter. Everyone in the group laughed the entire movie.
I found the smart-girl, methodical approach to sex hilarious. The supporting cast was great, especially Connie Britton. I liked that the ending was atypical as well.

I so wanted to like this flick. Lots of great people and I am actually quite a fan of Aubrey Plaza but this film was not funny. Everything seemed very forced and the actors seemed to be just going through the motions. Think of Anakin and Padme in Star Wars 2. So many funny people and such an unfunny film. Do not waste your time or $$$.
I saw this film only because of my interest in Aubrey Plaza as an actress. Horrible film with bad acting and Horrible plot. Would like to see the main actress in an intelligent film. This is not it.
Very funny; I think it's a different movie thank all the other comedies out there. I could not stop laughing

The summer comedy sex romp. You've seen it before, although most of the ones I remember center around male protagonists. This one follows Brandy Klark (Aubrey Plaza) as her graduating class's valedictorian, a well-studied, bookish, painfully honest and socially stunted lady who is worried about entering college with literally no sexual experiences under her belt. So to speak.

Hoping to get a little practice before game time, Brandy drafts a To Do List containing every sexual experience she can think of, including more than a few that she doesn't understand at all (shockers and pearl necklaces, to name a few). With the help of some of her friends, as well as a comedic cast of goofballs (including the fantastic Bill Hader and Andy Samberg), she will stumble through raunchy, nutty, and nearly X-rated experiences as she makes her way to the mostly pre-packaged ending that films like this seem required to have.

In spite of its pretty basic story and foregone conclusion, the film is funny, as long as you calibrate your sense of humor to its goals. After all, this is about as low brow as comedy gets. It's right there in the title. Even though there are more than a few stock characters, nearly every actor does their best and seems to be having fun doing it, which is infectious.

Congrats to Aubrey Plaza for her first top starring role. Innately charming and classically pretty (but not so gorgeous that she's unbelievable as the inexperienced nerd), she actually carried the movie a lot better than I expected her to. However, I still didn't feel, by the film's end, that she completely sold me on her character, especially in the very few moments when the script asks her to be dramatically sincere. She's got some great (developing) comedic chops, but her ability to convey honest emotions like dismay, hopelessness, or fear still isn't up to headliner quality.

These tarnished moments in the film's acting are rare, though. Definitely the kind of film you're better off watching with a group of close friends and maybe a box of wine or two, THE TO DO LIST achieves its meager goals with all the crass aplomb that you should expect. Look for anything more than that, and be prepared to be disappointed.
Really stupid, juvenile movie.  I made it 43 minutes in before turning it off forever.  The only good part was the trip back to the 90s in the opening credits.

"Not as much of a thrill as I would have expected like Youth in Revolt, this indie comedy from writer-director Maggie Carey is pretty much a funny, fuzzy, crude, and subtly done sex comedy that takes much of the coarse vulgarity one would find in something like John Waters, Clerks, or Zack and Miri... into the world of a Judd Apatow-inspired comedy about the coming-of-age.

While nothing too special, Aubrey Plaza's performance as timid, ambitious, and feminist-leading Brandey Klark is a character that many can relate to, boys and girls, and her sexual curiosity with the film title list is a one full of gross, silly sexual acts that line up to show that she can be a "cool kid" before she goes to Georgetown University. However, the film does not develop much from that point and goes right into the chaos. While the sex farce gets tiring and a bit redundant (with the exception of a few interesting discussions and dialogue that could serve as a 16 year old's portal to right or mostly wrong), it is the 1990s chic and set pieces that keep the film going also with one of the most exciting (and even dirtiest) soundtracks (Pearl Jam, MC Hammer, Naughty by Nature, 2 Live Crew) to a film this year.

What sets this film different to a film that opens the discussion about sexuality is that it is knowing of its subject matter in a way like Don Jon, a much better indie comedy-drama about sexual adventures and temptation. If you like Aubrey Plaza's deadpan, hipster flair in her work, you will definitely like this film but if not, do not come in expecting a whole lot other than teenage angst and lust."

"I'm witty, engaging, smart, well read. Once I add sexually experienced to the package he'll want me." After high school graduation valedictorian but sexually inactive Brandy Klark (Plaza) goes to her first real party and sees a guy that makes her feel things she never has before. Not wanting to embarrass herself she comes up with a list so she can get more experience before ultimately "losing it" to the man of her dreams. Since the Hangover hit R rated comedies have been more and more abundant. Since American Pie and There's Something About Mary teen based comedies have been trying to one up each other and see how much more they can get away with. This one goes pretty far in terms of shock factor and is funny for most of the way through. The only real negative I can say about this is like Bridesmaids this one seemed geared more toward the female crowd. A negative to me because I am a guy. Fans of movies like Bridesmaids and The Bachelorette will really enjoy this. Overall, it was funny and I did like it but was just a little too girly for me. I give it a B.

this review is on the blu ray disc of the movie -
movie - 2.5 / 5
video - 4 / 5
audio - 4 / 5

one of the worst movies i have watched whole year, didn't even make it to
the end, not funny at all. had high hopes after watching the trailer, but...
boring as hell..

we're the millers  was a much better movie.

I was one of the few to see the To-Do List in theaters.  It is very funny.  Aubrey Plaza is a delight and her character is likeable.  I've never seen Parks and Recreation - didn't know she was on it until recently.  I know Aubrey from Scott Pilgrim, Portlandia and her hilarious talk show appearances.

This movie tried to be funny but I found it to be crude. There was a lot of profanity, yes it was R. I don't feel I'm a prude but it seemed to be pushing the innuendo and profanity down your throat. The movie takes place in 1993 and is about a bunch of high school kids during summer break. One of the girls starts a 'to do list' of sexual acts she wants to perform on guys (any guys) and some I've never heard. I wanted to like it but it just wasn't funny. We're The Millers was also crude with lots of profanity but that was really funny.

This film takes the traditionally male-dominated genre of teen sex comedy and ramps it up to an uncomfortable, yet unbelievably hilarious, level.

The key to success here is not only the nostalgic flashback to the 90's (which proves to be somewhat of a comedy gold mine), but also the screenwriting, as well as Aubrey Plaza's performance. She rarely fails to bring something new, original, and funny to the table.

The female friendships in this film are almost as fun to track as the dysfunctional lead family. Overall, it's a winning combination. Plus, the soundtrack and cinematography are consistently ahead of most recent comedic films.

It's also quite fun to watch the cameos from favorites such as Donald Glover, Andy Samberg, and Bill Hader.

Overall, this film is a hilarious 'thrill ride', though NOT for the faint of heart. I strongly recommend The To Do List to any comedy lover looking for a fresh take on an old favorite.

Aubrey Plaza gets her first lead role as Brandy Klark the nerdy valedictorian of her high school class.  She also wears the big "V" sign and wants to eliminate it before heading off to college.  So with help from her somewhat experienced two best friends, Fiona (Alia Shawkat) and Wendy (Sarah Steele) and her encyclopedia, Brandy devises a sexual to-do list.

The premise isn't necessarily new, but historically it is the guys who develop the list in raunchy films like this one.  And yes, there are plenty of descriptive sexual moves that go well past the few better known ones.  In this film, unlike some of the similar themed ones of the past, the filmmakers pull their punches when it comes to actually showing anything.  All the action is below or above the camera lens or covered in heavy blankets.  Don't get me wrong, the film has its moments but this is more a titillating comedy, than a breast-fest.

Brandy uses people she knows like her lab partner, Cameron (Johnny Simmons), to get through some of the easier tasks (the movie was originally named "The Hand Job") unaware that he has a big crush on her.  Her ultimate goal is to lose her virginity (and more) to the hunky, older life guard (Scott Porter) where she works.  When it comes to detailed tips, Brandy must rely on her older, slutty sister Amber (Rachel Bilson) for information.  This of course, usually comes at a price.

Connie Britton and Clark Gregg get in a few good moments as Brandy's parents.  Andy Samberg, Donald Glover and Christopher Mintz-Plasse play characters that are little more than checkmarks on the list.  Bill Hader is pretty damn funny as well as Brandy's manager at the pool.  This is a nice summer diversion for those who won't be offended by some of the no-holds-barred-language.
Classic

I wanted to like it but to be honest I don't think I laughed at all. I did roll my eyes a lot though. I'm glad I didn't buy it...

Cute indie comedy that has a solid cast and some laugh out loud moments. The script meanders a bit and it takes a while to get going but all in all a pretty good "teen" comedy with very adult humor. I wish there has been more of it. Props to Rachel Bilson playing an R Rated version of her character on The OC.
